channel.title: Blogs on Kimberly Staudt
channel.description: Recent content in Blogs on Kimberly Staudt

item.title: Data Visualization
item.description: The purpose of this tutorial is to demonstrate how to plot data on a graph using the lahman baseball database. Open a new R Script.The following will need to be installed: lahman,ggplot2,ggiraph, and dplyr.This can be achieved by choosing the Install Packages option under the Tools tab. Once installed, pull from the library as seen below: library(Lahman) library(dplyr) FALSE FALSE Attaching package: 'dplyr' FALSE The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': FALSE FALSE filter, lag FALSE The following objects are masked from 'package:base': FALSE FALSE intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2) library(ggiraph) Now we can begin.

item.title: Data Visualization: Histograms and Bar Charts
item.description: The purpose of this tutorial is to demonstrate how to create histograms and barcharts using dplyr and the lahman data base. Histograms are useful when a variable is represented by a range of numbers rather than a single point (such as in line charts). Simularly, a bar chart measures the height (numerical value) of a variable. For example, if you survey a room of 100 people on their favorite color you may recieve the following random sample results: blue 45, red 12, purple 20, orange 13, yellow 8, and green 2.

item.title: Histograms 2
item.description: This is the second tutorial on creating historgrams via RStudio. Install the following and pull from the library: library(dplyr) library(Lahman) library(ggplot2) library(ggiraph) Extracting the Data In the last post, we assigned our extracted data to df(dataframe).Complete this step again. df<-Teams%>% filter(yearID==1980)%>% select(name,HR)%>% arrange(HR) str give the structure of whatever data you have. Store your data as a factor vector, rather than a character vector.The benefit to this is that factor vectors are organized into different levels .
